entry.content:
Ah, you must be that one troubled fellow on deciding which Lisp to use

You shall not take everything I say as the infallible truth, but let me put it down here. For you.

Use Common Lisp

If you want to be use a solid, hard rock stable, rich in history, full of features, tested in production and space Lisp.

Use Clojure

If you want a JVM first-class citizen Lisp.

Use Racket

If you want to learn Scheme, a Lisp dialect that has a lot of features to help you learn and be productive in your professional work.
